#â€‹582 â€” December 10, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

ğŸ—“ï¸ A quick note that Go Weekly will be moving to Fridays in January 2026. We still have one more week before the Christmas break, though: we'll be back next Wednesday with our 2025Â roundup!
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

Go Proposal: Secret Mode â€” Secret mode, set to land in Go 1.26 behind a flag, lets you run a function where, upon completion, the stack (and registers) will be automatically zeroed to ensure sensitive information doesnâ€™t stay in memory longer than necessary. Ideal for cryptography use cases, the API is simple enough that I expect to see it used moreÂ widely.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ The full, precise behavior of secret mode and other 'goroutine bubble' features is still being actively discussed,Â however.

Go App: Cloud Infrastructure from Startup to Scale â€” Deploy and scale a real Go app on AWS. Start fast with containers and App Runner, then grow into CI/CD, Terraform, ECS, and production-readyÂ infrastructure.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Hajime Hoshi, the creator of the fantastic Ebitengine 2D game engine, reflects on 12 years of building Ebitengine, shares some of the Ebitengine-powered games released in 2025, and lays out some futureÂ developments.

  • Reddit's /r/golang participants discussed their favorite 'don't do this' lessons learned working with Go overÂ time.

  • GoLand 2025.3, the latest version of JetBrains' popular commercial IDE for Go, has been released.

  • ğŸ¤ Russ Cox went on the ACM ByteCast podcast to talk about his background, meeting Go co-designer Rob Pike, as well as the role of Go in the modern developmentÂ landscape.

  • GitHub has improved its Dependabot-based dependency graphs for GoÂ projects.

ğŸ”¥Â This Developer Really Doesn't Like Gin â€” Itâ€™s easy to criticize something, but itâ€™s not so easy to put together several thousand words with numerous diagrams, tables, and examples to back up a rant. Even if you disagree with Efronâ€™s opinion, his treatise on why Gin is â€˜very badâ€™ is.. anÂ experience.

Efron Licht

Compressing Embedded Files in Go â€” If Go wonâ€™t do it, you can just do itÂ yourself.

Vincent Bernat

ğŸ“„ Malicious Go Packages Impersonate Googleâ€™s UUID Library Kirill Boychenko (Socket)

ğŸ“„ Go Optimizations for High Volume Services â€“ Lessons from a Postgres to ElasticsearchÂ pipeline. Julien Singler

ğŸ“„ Go Escape Analysis and Why My Function Return Worked Bonnie Simon

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

RobotGo 1.0: Native Cross-Platform GUI Automation â€” A way to control the pointer, keyboard, read the screen, etc. on macOS, Windows, and Linux (X11). A separate paid version adds Wayland support.

V Caesar et al.

Gremlins: A Mutation Testing Tool for Small Go Modules â€” A different way to put your code, and associated tests, through a stress test with some gremlins mutating your code to see if the tests stand up to scrutiny. Itâ€™s early days, but worth checking out for the logo alone! GitHubÂ repo.

Davide Petilli

Meet Agentic Postgres: The Database Built for AI Agents â€” Spin up Postgres for AI experiments in seconds. Free forever, with forks, vector search, and zeroÂ setup.

Tiger Data sponsor

filesql: SQL Driver for CSV, TSV, XLSX Files, and More â€” Built atop SQLite, filesql provides SQL access to CSV, TSV, LTSV, Parquet, and Excel (XLSX) files fromÂ Go.

CHIKAMATSU Naohiro

Kaiju Engine: A 2D and 3D Game Engine in Go â€” A â€˜work in progressâ€™ project to create a game engine in Go that uses Vulkan behind the scenes. Itâ€™s still early days, however. GitHubÂ repo.

Brent Farris et al.

gorush 1.20: A Push Notification Server, Built on Gin â€” Supports APNS (Apple Push Notification Service), Firebase (FCM), and HMS Push Server (Huawei).

Bo-Yi Wu

  • ğŸ¤– Crush 0.22+ â€“ Charm's Go-powered coding agent tool continues to get even better with v0.22 introducing the ability to search the Web (using DuckDuckGo) and now supporting tools and MCPs that returnÂ images.

  • neo4j-go-driver v6.0 â€“ Official Go driver for working with Neo4j databases using the BoltÂ protocol.

  • GoFr 1.50 â€“ The opinionated microservice development framework adds Azure File StorageÂ support.

  • parquet-go v0.26.0 â€“ Low-footprint library for reading and writing ParquetÂ files.

  • Casbin 3.0 â€“ Open-source access control library for GoÂ projects.

  • Lazygit 0.57 â€“ Simple terminal UI for gitÂ commands.

  • go-github 80.0 â€“ Client library for the GitHub APIÂ v3.

  • Ebitengine 2.9.5 â€“ The 2D gameÂ engine.

  • dskDitto 0.1 â€“ Fast duplicate file finder.

  • fq 0.16 â€“ Like jq for binaryÂ formats.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • Dolt, a version-controlled relational database built with Go, is now boasting being as fast as MySQL on the Sysbench benchmark.

  • Brian 'Beej' Hall, famous for his various guides for things like network programming and Git, has released Beej's Guide to Learning Computer Science. It's high level and more about the mental models and philosophy of problem solving than any actual coding orÂ math.

  • ğŸ§ Microsoft has launched a VS Code Insiders podcast where the VS Code team gets to go "beyond the release notes" and talk about VS Code's features andÂ ecosystem.

  • Let's Encrypt is celebrating ten years of generatingÂ certificates.

  • Want to try and understand how elliptic curve cryptography works? Here's an attempt at boiling it down.

item.title: ã€Reddit's migration from Python to Goã€‘Reddit ä» Python è¿ç§»åˆ° Go
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹581 â€” December 3, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Getting Started with Go on the Nintendo 64 â€” EmbeddedGo is a fork of the standard Go compiler that adds support for bare-metal compilation targeting numerous devices, now including the nearly 30 year old Nintendo 64 console. What a fantasticÂ experiment!

Timur Ã‡elik

Bots Abuse Free Trials. WorkOS Radar StopsÂ Them â€” Free trials attract growth, but they also invite abuse. Cursor uses WorkOS Radar to detect fake accounts in real time through device fingerprinting and behavioral signals, blocking fraud before it drains compute or disrupts realÂ users.

WorkOS sponsor

The Type-Safe Error Checking Proposal â€” Anton continues his look at accepted language proposals that will arrive in future versions of Go. This time, itâ€™s errors.AsType, a modern, type-safe alternative to errors.As arriving in GoÂ 1.26.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ Anton has also taken a look at Go 1.26's enhancements to goroutineÂ metrics.

IN BRIEF:

  • Go 1.25.5 and 1.24.11 have both been released. They're minor point releases including two security fixes in crypto/x509.

  • Earlier this year, Microsoft began porting the TypeScript compiler to Go â€“ now they have a progress update on how it's going noting "TypeScript 7 often sees close to a 10x speedup over the 6.0 compiler on fullÂ builds!"

Modernizing Reddit's Backend Infrastructure (with Go) â€” Redditâ€™s system was entirely built on a handful of Python-powered services but in 2024 they began migrating to Go, with the commenting system (the biggest and most heavily used system) now entirely moved over. Hereâ€™s a look at how they did it and what they learned along theÂ way.

Katie Shannon (Reddit)

Reddit Discusses: Why are Interfaces Implicit? â€” One user asks â€œWhy are interface implementations implicit? It makes it so much harder to see which structs implement which interfacesâ€ which leads to lots of discussion, as you mightÂ imagine.

Reddit

Tiger Lake: Unified Real-Time Architecture for Go Systems â€” Tiger Lake bridges Postgres and your lakehouse for continuous data flow. Power dashboards, monitoring, and agentic systems with live, contextual data in one Postgres-nativeÂ platform.

Tiger Data sponsor

ğŸ“„ 'Re-exec' Testing Go Subprocesses â€“ An alternative approach to testing Go code that spawnsÂ subprocesses. Redowan Delowar

ğŸ“„ Go Still Supports Building Non-Module Programs with GOPATH Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Avoiding Splintered Failure Modes in Go Redowan Delowar

ğŸ“„ Minimizing Identifier Scope in Go Fillmore Labs

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

go-size-analyzer: Analyze the Size of Dependencies in Compiled Go Binaries â€” Supporting ELF, Mach-O, PE, and even WebAssembly binary formats, this tool lets you get a detailed size breakdown by packages and sections contained within your Go-compiled binaries so you can see what all those bytes are being used for. Thereâ€™s also an online version to try which worked extremely quickly in myÂ testing.

Zxilly

Gitmal: A Static Page Generator for Repos â€” You know how GitHub lets you navigate your repo and read docs and code in a well-formatted, structured way? Gitmal generates the same output but in static form for hosting wherever you like. A neat idea! Hereâ€™s a liveÂ demo.

Anton Medvedev

Katana 1.3: A Web Crawling and Spidering Framework â€” A flexible Go-powered Web crawling tool (which can also be used as a library from Go) that can work in both headless and non-headless modes and has lots of customizableÂ features.

ProjectDiscovery

  • GoReleaser 2.13 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms. Now with support for publishing MCPs to the GitHub MCP registry.

  • Unioffice 2.7 â€“ A commercial, pure Go library for working with Word, Excel and PowerPoint files.

  • Open Policy Agent (OPA) 1.11 â€“ CNCF graduated, general-purpose policyÂ engine.

  • Lego 4.29 â€“ Let's Encrypt/ACME client andÂ library.

  • Kubo 0.39 â€“ An IPFS implementation inÂ Go.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Wasting hours debugging AI code alone? Tuple brings your team together to figure it out andÂ ship.

Drop-in e-signatures for your app â€” BoldSign SDK with sample code, webhooks, and a free sandbox. Get your free APIÂ key.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ”’ Let's Encrypt has announced that it's gradually reducing the validity period of certificates it issues from 90 days to 45 days over the next two years. If you have a process for obtaining certificates from them, you'll want to ensure it's robust enough to handle theÂ change.

  • ğŸ„ Puzzlers rejoice! Advent of Code is back for another year. This time we get 12 days of puzzles instead of the usual 25, making it easier to complete.. weÂ hope!

  • Ever fancied analyzing the millions of posts and comments on Hacker News? ClickHouse has released a 55GB dataset, complete with vector embeddings.

  • If you're an AWS user, you might want to get up to speed with the announcements from AWS re:Invent 2025 this week: AWS Lambda Managed Instances and AWS Lambda durable functions are of particularÂ note.

  • Matt Godbolt's Advent of Compiler Optimisations 2025 is making for good reading soÂ far. It's not about Go but most compilers will take advantage of the sort of optimizationsÂ covered.

ã€

#â€‹580 â€” November 26, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

ğŸ“… This is a rather early note, but Go Weekly will be moving to Fridays in January 2026, as part of a schedule reshuffle for most of ourÂ newsletters.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

The 2025 Go Cryptography State of the Union â€” A detailed slide-rich transcript and video of Filippoâ€™s GopherCon presentation about Goâ€™s cryptography standard libraries: last yearâ€™s work gave Gophers enhanced abilities to address future vulnerabilities and comply with rigorousÂ standards.

Filippo Valsorda

Tiger Data Taught AI to Write Real Postgres Code. Try it Today â€” Tiger Data taught AI how to write idiomatic Postgres and open-sourced it. pg-aiguide brings real DB expertise to Claude Code, or any other MCP-enabledÂ tool.

Tiger Data sponsor

â–¶Â Â Advancing Go Garbage Collection with Green Tea â€” Michael of the Go team deftly explains how Goâ€™s garbage collection works and how the new so-called â€˜green teaâ€™ approach will make things better by default in Go 1.26. The official Go blog has an article about this topic if youâ€™d rather read thanÂ watch.

Michael Knyszek

ğŸ’¡ SPOILER: We also find out why 'green tea' is so-called: Austin Clements created the prototype while cafe-crawling in Japan drinking 'lots of matcha.'

IN BRIEF:

  • v0.45.0 of golang.org/x/crypto has been tagged to address two security issues in crypto/ssh and crypto/ssh/agent (CVE-2025-58181 and CVE-2025-47914 respectively).

  • Go 1.26's 'development freeze' occurs today meaning that any new features going into Go 1.26 must have been committed by now. You can learn more about Go's release cycle here.

  • The Go team's latest meeting notes mention a few '2026 planning' items including future work on scalability, runtime.free, and SIMDÂ support.

  • ğŸ“º A list of the top 15 most watched recordings of Go talks so far thisÂ year.

Using Docker to Deal with cgo Build Complexity â€” Goâ€™s toolchain makes it easy to build binaries for different systems, but if your project has any dependencies that rely on cgo, things rapidly get more complex. Hereâ€™s how the Dolt team uses Docker to make thingsÂ easier.

Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

ğŸ“„ A Million Ways to Die From a Data Race in Go Philippe Gaultier

ğŸ“„ Why I Built My Own Static Site Generator in Go Duy Ng

ğŸ“„ Graceful Shutdown in Go PaweÅ‚ Grzybek

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

RegreSQL: Regression Testing for Postgres Queries â€” A look into a Go-powered tool for applying Postgresâ€™s own regression testing methodology to your SQL queries in order to verify that changes, whether to your queries or schema, donâ€™t break how you expect those queries to work (e.g. are the right indexes or scan types still beingÂ used?)

Radim Marek

Goyek 3.0: A Go Library for Task Automation â€” A simple, cross-platform task automation library (think make-like) where tasks are defined in a Cobra-like style and the actions have a unit test feel. v3 has some breakingÂ changes.

goyek

Macroscope - The Best AI Code Review Tool for Go â€” The highest bug detection rates for Go on the market. Use discount code MACROGO to get 50% off your first 2Â months!

Macroscope sponsor

Tinyauth: An Easy Way to Secure Apps with a Login Screen â€” A Go-powered single binary way to add OAuth and LDAP support in a middleware-fashion in front of your webapps, even if theyâ€™re not written in Go. â–¶ï¸ Hereâ€™s a video demonstrating how to use it in front of any Docker-powered app. GitHubÂ repo.

Tinyauth Team

  • ğŸ¤– Agent Development Kit (ADK) for Go 0.2 â€“ Google's model-agnostic toolkit for building and deploying AIÂ agents.

  • Goa 3.23 â€“ DSL for buildingÂ microservices. "The code generator has been optimized to be over 80% faster."

  • go-redis 9.17 â€“ Official Go Redis clientÂ library. Adds support for Redis 8.4 and its newÂ commands.

  • River 0.28 â€“ Fast & reliable Postgres-powered background jobs system forÂ Go.

  • pgweb 0.17 â€“ Web-based, cross-platform PostgresÂ client.

  • Resty 2.17 â€“ Simple HTTP and REST clientÂ library.

  • ğŸ¤– Eino 0.7 â€“ LLM/AI app dev framework forÂ Go.

  • webdav 5.10 â€“ Standalone WebDAVÂ server.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • âš ï¸ For years, GitHub has reported secrets/tokens 'leaked' in Git repos to the original providers so they can be revoked, but now it's reporting secrets in unlisted GitHub Gist postsÂ too (no they're notÂ private).

  • ğŸ§Ÿ This news would have been funnier on October 31, but AWS has resurrected CodeCommit from the dead. CodeCommit was is AWS's private Git repo hosting platform and it's generally availableÂ again.

  • Git 3.0 will default to using 'main' as the default branch.

  • Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL now supports Postgres 18.

  • How about solving FizzBuzz with cosines?

item.title: ã€Sixteen great years of Goã€‘Go çš„åå…­å¹´
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹579 â€” November 19, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

ğŸ‚Â Go Turns Sixteen Years Old â€” Go was open sourced sixteen years ago, and thereâ€™s much to be excited about in both the recent past and the near future. Austin gives a mini â€˜state of Goâ€™ in this post covering core language and library improvements, as well as some exciting DX and MCP-related changes that will keep Gophers happy and productive. â€œGo has an exciting year ahead of it,â€ AustinÂ concludes.

Austin Clements (Go Team)

Go Fullstack without Frameworks â€” Join Maximiliano Firtman for this detailed video course, and discover how to code a performant fullstack app, from scratch, using Vanilla JavaScript and Go. You'll cover web components, dynamic client-side routing, View Transitions, data filtering, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Context-Aware Dialer Methods Coming to Go 1.26 â€” First proposed four years ago, context-aware, network-specific methods are coming to net.Dialer in early 2026. Anton looks at how theyâ€™ll work and why you might want to use them (for cancellation â€“ which you might currently use DialContextÂ for).

Anton Zhiyanov

How We Avoided Side-Channels in Our New Post-Quantum Go Cryptography Libraries â€” The libraries in question are ml-dsa (FIPS-204) and go-slh-dsa (FIPS-205) if you want to kick theÂ tires.

Scott Arciszewski

The Benefits of Using an Open Source IDP Design On AWS â€” See how OSS+AWS enables flexible IDP workflows, strong governance, and zero lock-in. No downloadÂ required.

Fairwinds sponsor

ğŸ“„ Rust vs Go: Memory Management â€“ Reaches an interesting conclusion: â€œGo saves your time now, Rust saves CPU timeÂ later.â€ vpoltora

ğŸ“„ Getting Started with Fuzzing in Go â€“ A still valuable official tutorial we havenâ€™t linked inÂ years. Go Docs

ğŸ“„ Building Dolt on Windows: The 'Pacman' Game Elian Deogracia-Brito

ğŸ“„ Testing Out Crush, Charm's TUI-Based Coding Agent Graham Helton

ğŸ“„ Profiling Go Programs with pprof and k6 Pears

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Wave Terminal: 'AI-Native' Open Source Go-Powered TerminalÂ App â€” Available for MacOS, Linux, and Windows, Wave integrates features like file previews, file editing, browsing, working with remote files and machines, and the like. Being written in Go is aÂ bonus. GitHubÂ repo.

Command Line Inc.

Guts: Convert Go Types to TypeScript â€” A code generation tool (that you use as a library, however) that can convert Go types to TypeScript so you can get consistent types across the frontend and backend of a full-stack app, say. Could be a good fit if you donâ€™t need something as broad as TypeSpec or OpenAPI,Â say.

Coder

ğŸ’¡ tscriptify is also an option if you'd prefer a pure CLI tool. Or, perhaps, Tygo for the best of both worlds (CLI tool andÂ library).

goquery v1.11: jQuery-Like HTML/DOM Manipulation Methods â€” An approach for working with HTML and CSS from Go that tries to stick closely to the jQuery way of doing things. You can see all its supported functionsÂ here.

Martin Angers and Contributors

Scriggo: Template Engine and Go Embeddable Interpreter â€” If youâ€™re familiar with something like ERB in Ruby/Rails, this is a similar idea in a Go flavor and lets you use Go to script things with templates (and said templates can be changed on the fly and operate without beingÂ recompiled).

Open2b Software Snc.

Furgit: Fast Implementation of Git in Pure Go â€” Note: GPLÂ licensed.
Runxi Yu

  • Bubble Tea 2.0 RC 2 â€“ The popular TUI framework introduces synchronized output updates, enabled byÂ default.

  • ğŸ” gokey v0.2 â€“ A simple vaultless password manager built atÂ Cloudflare.

  • River 0.27 â€“ Fast & reliable Postgres-powered background jobs system forÂ Go.

  • Boxes and Glue v0.1.10 â€“ PDF rendering library for Go using TeX algorithms.

  • gRPC-Go 1.77 â€“ Go implementation of gRPC for HTTP/2 basedÂ RPC.

  • Go Stripe v84.0 â€“ The official Go client library for Stripe.

  • Buf 1.60 â€“ CLI tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • Go Rate Limiter 1.1

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ Tuple - how developers at Shopify, Figma, and Stripe collaborate on code. Stop dictating and take control withÂ Tuple.

Software Engineer - Join our "kick ass" team! Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers to join ourÂ team.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • Git 2.52 has been released with a variety of minor features, including a new git last-modified command for determining which commit most recently modified each file in a given directory.

  • If you were trying to get any work done yesterday, you may have noticed that Cloudflare went down for a few hours, taking numerous other services with it. They've already published a fantastic, in-depth incident report of the cause, and it's something that could easily crop up in your own systems.

  • ğŸ¤– Google introduced the hotly awaited preview of Gemini Pro 3 yesterday. My experiments show it functions very well for coding purposes. Here's a developer-oriented guide to what's new. GitHub Copilot has also already addedÂ support.

  • ğŸ¤– An ardent critic of LLMs spent a month doing 'chat oriented programming' and while he found the experience "infuriating", he concedes it has merit and is a viable option "if your tolerance for pain is high enough.".

  • A quick recipe for rate-limiting requests with Nginx.
